title: Umborne Brook
text:
Umbourne Brook is a watercourse in <a href="Devon">Devon</a>, England. In rises south-east of <a href="Upottery">Upottery</a> and runs past the villages of <a href="Widworthy">Widworthy</a> and <a href="Wilmington%2C%20Devon">Wilmington</a> then joins the <a href="River%20Coly">River Coly</a> at <a href="Colyton%2C%20Devon">Colyton</a>. The Coly joins the <a href="River%20Axe%20%28Lyme%20Bay%29">River Axe</a> which discharges into the English Channel between <a href="Seaton%2C%20Devon">Seaton</a> and <a href="Axmouth">Axmouth</a>.
<a href="Tristram%20Risdon">Tristram Risdon</a>, writing in called the stream the "little river Womborne", and <a href="Richard%20Polwhele">Richard Polwhele</a>, 1797, referred to it as "The Omber or Wombern". The name has the same derivation as "<a href="Wimborne">Wimborne</a>" in Dorset, from <a href="Old%20English">Old English</a> "wimm" meaning a meadow. The stream gives its name to Womberford, a <a href="ford%20%28crossing%29">ford</a> at a now-lost location in the parish of <a href="Cotleigh">Cotleigh</a>.
